Betrayal Legacy
item.comment: The first game (prologue) is the best game of betrayal I've ever played. It's really fun and engaging. 7 games later, I haven't enjoyed a single game since. Utterly frustrating and disappointing. The traitor has never won a game save for once when we played the rules incorrectly. There's no ongoing story at all. Feels like I got tricked and I have no interest in finishing the campaign.

Einstein: His Amazing Life and Incomparable Science
Epic Card Game
item.comment:
I resent a lot of the people who claim this "fixes" magic. It essentially removes mana and mana cards do make some games of magic devolve if you don't draw any but mana is also the engaging economy and one of the strategic puzzles in magic. It also removes a lot of the strategy, tactics, and choice that exist in magic. There's a reason that they've never printed a viable card that single-handedly destroys all creatures during your opponents turn in magic. There's a reason magic has never printed a 7-power creature which can attack, unopposed, on the first turn in magic (cheesy combos not withstanding)...
Epic isn't a bad game (though I didn't like it) but a lot of the timing and choices and restriction that make magic a compelling game for millions of players are stripped from Epic so just be aware of who you're recommending it to.

item.name: Lucky's Misadventures: Episode 42 – Lost in Oddtopia
item.comment:
Maybe this game doesn't work well with 2 players but the general issues I had with this game seem so glaring that I cant believe how generally positive people are on this game. The only explanation is that these are all kickstarter backers and I'm the only person who bought this elsewhere and whose opinion isn't colored by the kickstarter process of hype and anticipation.
First off, setup for the game is on page 12 of the rulebook. There are pages and pages before that of card explanations which, without having gotten to any rules yet, completely out of context. And then the game rules themselves are written in an often over-complicated way and interspersed with asides from the designer about how hilarious his playgroup is (e.g. it says just for fun that you can stop a person's turn and force everyone to simultaneously point at who they each think is winning... yeehaw.) By the end of the game we were unable to figure out when some phases occur, what some cards do, and on top of all that we kept cringing at the publishing choices like instead of revealing 3 cards from a deck each round (which is the actual gameplay rule) you're supposed to pound the table and scream, "eat a toad !," three times or something like that while you reveal the 3 cards from a deck. The "toad" here has no relevance to anything else and appears to only exist as an opportunity for more cringing.
Then there's these cards that dictate which abilities in your hand will trigger each round which felt like such an arbitrary mechanism. I know you can hold cards in your hand from round to round to wait until they will trigger but why make timing your cards such an unpleasant, random experience when one - timing in this game can be critical and two - the abilities generally are reeeally boring anyway so there's no sense of payoff when you do wait. Examples include: "play 1 more card this turn" or "your opponent plays 1 less card this turn" or "your opponent can't make you discard cards this turn". Those abilities wouldn't be so bad if they weren't ~90% of all the card abilities. I've never seen such milk-toast, boring abilities in a deck building game. Having played many deckbuilders, my opponent and I spent the second half of the game consistently looking at the buy row with plenty of money and opting to buy nothing. And not because the cards were bad compared to wait we'd already bought before, but they were just more of the same boring cards which were already clogging our decks. By the end of the game my whole deck felt like a giant clog.
Finally there's the tinker and wicked business. You only get to play 3 cards per turn which, best case scenario, grant 2 money each, so getting enough money to buy a card that costs 9 is ridiculous (why even have cards that expensive??? even 6 money would have been an incredible feat to obtain and never happened once during our game). So there are 2 other kinds of cards which give no money but rather an opportunity to get those uber-expensive cards for free. You might think you should focus on getting lots of tinker or wicked but you need both because if you ignore either, your opponent will consistently get those incredibly expensive cards for free. And even if you do focus on getting tinker and wicked power, if you don't have the right one when the cards that cost 7+ are randomly drawn from the deck, you're out of luck. There's likely 0 chance you can buy them with money and a great chance your opponent will have a couple tinker and can snatch game winning cards for a pittance.
In fairness to the game, the rulebook does say, "don't take the game too seriously" but I wish the publisher and/or designer would have taken their design and development a little more seriously. In my many years gaming I've played several games that are worse than Lucky's Misadventures but at least my group had fun laughing at how random or ridiculous they were; this one, however, was an absolute pile.
All that said, the art is OK.

Twilight Imperium: Third Edition – Shattered Empire
Twilight Inscription
item.comment:
I don't think should really be compared to twilight imperium and it really shouldn't be compared to most roll and writes.
This is a strategy game on the longer side (2 hours or so) for people who enjoy working towards combos and lots of moving parts and want a little player interaction but largely enjoy working on their own engines. The twilight imperium theme is great for me but that's the icing on the cake; this game has been a hit in its own right with everyone I've shown it to so far.
